Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT-WEDS10 
    

      The Cox News Service spot news budget for Wednesday June 10,
1998.
      c.1998 Cox News Service

   This is the Cox News Service spot news budget for Wednesday June
10, 1998. We will update this budget at 6 p.m. ET.

   Separate feature and commentary budgets move at 10 a.m. ET
Monday-Friday. Separate sports and business budgets move at 5 p.m.
Monday-Friday.

   If you have questions or need a resend, please call CoxNet, the
Cox News Service, at 404-526-5456. The night news editor, until 10
p.m. ET, is Todd C. Duncan at 404-582-7282.

   With questions about Washington-originated material, please call
our Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338.

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316.

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334.

   WASHINGTON

   ONLINEADS _ A Texas tax exempt organization promoting school
vouchers appears to be the first group in the country to send paid,
political advertising to thousands of computer users via the
Internet. So-called issue ads on the Internet are just the tip of
the iceberg. Soon to come will be candidates sending electronic
campaign litterature to voters and issue ad campaigns that will
prompt voters to e-mail their members of Congress on pending
legislation, all at the click of a button. (Foskett, Cox News
Service).

   KIM _ WASHINGTON _ President Clinton holds a joint news
conference with President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea at 3:30 p.m.
EDT. (Deans, Cox News Service). EDs: An updated budget line will
move following the news conference.

   TOBACCO _ WASHINGTON _ Senate backers of a national tobacco bill
make their first attempt Tuesday to cut off debate on the bill and
move toward a vote. The Senate also considers an amendment by Sen.
Paul Coverdell, R-Ga., to use proceeds from the bill to beef up
drug interdiction forces. (Lipman, Cox News Service).

   GINGRICH _ Newt Gingrich's latest financial disclosures indicate
an unusually high percentage of contributions from small donors,
perhaps an indication that he has more grass roots support than
usually thought. (Sherman, Cox News Service).

   ENCRYPTION _ WASHINGTON _ FBI Director Louis Freeh meets Tuesday
with top computer industry executives to discuss whether
investigators should be able to unscramble sensitive electronic
messages. (Glass, Cox News Service).

   HIGHWAYS-TEXAS _ WASHINGTON _ How Texas fared in the final
version of the huge transportation authorization bill. (Harlan, Cox
News Service).

   NATIONAL

   BAPTIST _ SALT LAKE CITY _ Coverage of the opening of the
Southern Baptist Convention, including the presidential election
and a vote on an amendment to the ``Statement of Faith'' that says,
among other things, marriage is between a man and a woman and wives
should be subservient to their husbands. (White, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   BISHOP-PROFILE _ He's a man who prays almost as much as he
breathes. He's a man who not only gives inspirational books to
friends but also takes the time to mark pages he thinks will boost
their spiritual deficits. He is a living history of Florida
catholicism, someone who helped shepherd the explosive growth from
80,000 faithful in 1945 to more than 2.5 million today. But, now,
he's also the highest ranking Catholic in U.S. history to leave his
job for molesting a child. (Houck, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   RUDOLPH _ MURPHY, N.C. _The owner of a storage mini-warehouse in
Murphy is auctioning off the stuff Eric Rudolph left behind in a
storage locker. We check out what's auctioned and who shows.
(Harmon, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   NERVE _ Reaction from Vietnam veterans and other veteran groups
to CNN-Time report that the U.S. military used nerve gas on a
mission to kill Americans who defected during the Vietnam War. The
Pentagon will investigate. Then-Defense Secretary Melvin Laird said
the U.S. military shipped a ``small amount'' of sarin nerve gas to
Vietnam in 1967 but never used it. (Brice, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   EXECUTION _ David Cargill is scheduled to be executed at 7 p.m.
by the state of Georgia for killing the parents of four small
children. (Cook, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   TEXAS-BUGS _ WACO, Texas _ An unseasonably dry spring has
squelched what could have been a horrendous year for bugs, giving
residents a break from the normal battles fought with tiny critters
in Central Texas. The latest rainfall, however, could change that.
Much of the insect population is down this year, particularly
mosquitoes. (Everitt, Waco Tribune-Herald) MOVED.

   SCIENCE/MEDICINE

   BOXING-FITNESS _ Boxing and its close cousin, kickboxing, have
become the wunderworkouts of choice for the Hollywood A-list, both
on- and off-screen, from Jodie Foster to Ally McBeal. Fitness
boxing is becoming increasingly popular outside Hollywood, too.
Unlike regular boxing, fitness boxing and kickboxing involve no
actual sparring _ except with a heavy bag. But the workout is
incredibly demanding; devotees say it's the toughest exercise
they've ever tried. (Kim, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MONSTERS _ As sci-fi and monster movies increasingly depict kids
at risk _ and spin off toys that appeal to very young kids _
parents need to arm their kids with two weapons: common sense and
sleep. Atlanta psychologist Stephen Garber, author of ``Monsters
Under the Bed and Other Childhood Fears,'' says kids under 8 or 9
really can't distinguish reality and fantasy. (Lore, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   MELANOMA-VACCINE _ The search for a melanoma vaccine is a
microscopic detective story that shows how fast things change in
the treatment of this deadliest form of skin cancer. Evidence
mounts that vaccines could be not only more effective, but cheaper
and with fewer toxic side effects than other treatments for
malignant melanoma. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) MOVED.

   WITH

   MELANOMA-PROTECTION _ Don't throw away your sunscreen, beg
dermatologists who worry that people have been confused by accounts
of a recent research report indicating sunscreens do not lower the
risk of malignant melanoma. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) MOVED.

   WITH

   MELANOMA-SIDEBAR _ Melanoma facts. (Staff, Dayton Daily News)
MOVED.

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
